WRITING.TEXT: Yes. If you have a RGH/JTAG modchip then you can just put any 2tb hdd into your 360. It's just a simple step to format it in the Microsoft Dashboard. If you don't have a modchip it can still be done by hacking the hard drive so it identifies as a standard xbox 360 hard drive, but that's probably complicated and wouldn't work on all drives. Also you can buy a new 360 internal hard drive enclosure on eBay or Amazon for 5-10 dollars.

SATA is standardized. I never opened an official 360 enclosure as I use my official hdd in my secondary unmodified 360. If you have a trinity you should also ask whoever mods it if they can add an internal usb.
Clear your cache. Check for updates. Also make sure the game data on the hdd is not corrupted. It's probably the first.

Most of them, it would be easier to search for exclusive titles then cross reference each of those to verify none were eventually ported. Some Xbox 360 exclusive titles were exclusive in the sense that they were not on PS3. Oh look, someone already did that https://www.reddit.com/r/xbox360/comments/7z4sts/master_list_for_xbox_360_exclusivesnonpc

The 360 had wired controllers, other than cheap third-party options? I thought they were all wireless and you would just use a long charge cable if you killed the battery. I've never seen an official 360 wired controller in the wild, at least not that I have had nor did my friends. I had friends with cheap aftermarket wired controllers, though.

Why the alternate account? I'll just assume it's for multiplayer as it probably won't matter. I assume that yes it works the same on XB360 and XBOne. If you own both accounts then I see no reason not to keep both accounts on all your consoles. The purchases are tied to the account of purchase, but other accounts can access the purchased content if the other accounts are on the same console. There may be limits imposed by Microsoft in extreme cases, but normally you'll be just fine in normal use scenarios.

I'd just double check that light color. Is the console light green and the controller light solid green on any port indicator? If so then yeah the xbox 360 is indeed working just fine, you better double check the input selection on the TV and the HDMI cable. If you have different lights on the console or the controller is flashing then you have a problem with the console.

I rather like having content downloaded onto the system. It's safe, cause it's saved. Hard drives and flash media still outlast DVDs. I actually really liked the rumored no optical media xbone. Not the execution of the idea, but the rumor, because part of the rumor was that Microsoft was going to give digital copies for some games if you turned in the optical media. Of course they didn't do that. I was, however, ready to hit the gamestop and buy up dozens or maybe hundreds of scratched games to perminantly link them to my account.
Changing the DNS would help only on domain lookups. It will NOT help with downloading once the download has begun.

I didn't even know diabetics had a special diet. I thought they just had to avoid eating a few high sugar foods. I even just did a search online and it still seems to me he should have just asked for the chicken or fish and those options probably would have worked. Sorry for my ignorance, but I have an uncle who is diabetic, and I've known many other people who have one type or another. I can't ever recall them turning down food for anything except sugar content. Update: I looked it up, and like 95% of what I typically eat is already diabetic friendly food. Also Lemon herb chicken with a side of asparagus and red pepper was on the WestJet menu! That's like THE recommended meal for a diabetic according to most health websites.

Well yeah, if you have a special request you should expect to pay more. It's not like he's adding extra pickles. He's making an obscure, "make me a diabetic meal" request, clearly without telling them what that means. Why didn't he just order the fish or chicken? Diabetics can eat those... I checked. Modded Warfare on YouTube has many guides, but most guides, including his, are somewhat outdated. Basically, once you have dashlaunch and the Aurora dashboard you're pretty much all set. Get games in GOD format or rip them directly from the MS dashboard. Configure dashlaunch for liveblock, and autofake, but not livestrong as that will prevent your dashboard from downloading game assets. Some people still prefer FSD3, I think aurora presents a better interface. I can tell you that you that an unofficial update to the backwards compatibility files needed to play xbox original titles was released on 02 November 2019. It's on twitter and is based on the official 2018 backwards compatibility. This unofficial update is for developer and modified consoles. Also, avoid plug-ins. There's some for stealth live services which may be helpful for playing online. However, many are known to cause issues with certain games. This includes the Nova plugin in Aurora and the FSD3 plugin. Disable them.

You need more credit, or higher limits on the cards you have. Don't open more than 2 new accounts per year, and don't have more than 3-4 active credit cards in total. Accept any offered credit increases on these cards, as long as they don't start charging you a fee. In a few years diversify your credit with a car loan or mortgage as that's a bonus too. I suggest a card with a good cash back deal. Read the fine print and pay off all your purchases twice a month to ensure that you don't pay interest. Use a card like cash, and keep your cash as a buffer of at least 2x whatever you spend on the card. So if you have 1000 in the bank, spend at most 500. A few years ago I opened up a Discover card with 5% cash back, with a special offer so they match the cash back you earned. I paid no fees, but I made over 800 in cash back, which I used to pay off my card. You can even buy Amazon gift cards at the grocery store and make 10% back if you do it right. Now I have a credit limit 4x what they started me with, and 1/3 my annual salary on that one card alone.
I had a landlord turn me down for the apartment I needed for a college internship because of student loans totaling 10k at the time. I don't know what my credit score was, but it wasn't bad.

I suggest converting the ISO to Games On Demand (GOD) format.

It's better most of the time. Only exception I know is Alien Isolation, which should be either extracted or copied from the original disc using the Microsoft NXE dashboard. It's better because all the game data is neatly contained in a package, one formatted to take up less space on the disk. Remember, the xbox uses a version of FAT, but with a larger cluster size. Meaning every file has a min size and must be padded to accommodate the file system. If you have lots of small files you will lose lots of space. Each file in a GOD is already the perfect size to not waste any cluster space. There are other reasons, but that could be a significant source of wasted space. You also don't have to worry about multiple game discs, like ever, if using GOD. Just put both discs in the same folder and it just works.
I don't know, I recall a rebuild ISO option. Is that what you mean?

2 disc games often have one disc which installs data and the other for playing. Either install the data from the GOD or extract it to manually copy. Then delete the install disc, keep the installed data.

I mean that the install disc is not the game. The installation disc just copies data to your hdd. You can do this manually, in fact sometimes it seems you must do it manually. Just extract the data from the GOD or ISO and copy only what you need, it should be obvious when you see the directory structure on the disc. The install data normally goes to the save game folder /00000001/ or addon dlc folder /00000002/. This is not the GOD folder /00007000/ where you put the most games.

That guy in the video clearly has no experience. If he had experience he would know that river can only be passed by a transformer, and he ain't no Optimus Prime. There was this jeep trail in Colorado, often a stream was running through the road. I remember many times it was little more than a ditch, sometimes it would be 30 feet across. The runoff from the winter always caused it to swell, and when the road was open in the winter it would still flow or freeze over. Many times I turned back if it was bad, but a few occasions I had water halfway up the tires. I even had the tires covered in the middle of the stream on one occasion. Scary shit. But, I built up years of experience before I ever tried anything extreme.

Raspberry pi is a terrible option. It may work for a while, but you're going to be at 100% cpu every time it has to transcode a single video, also the ethernet and USB ports share the same USB 2.0 bus, so good luck trying to get 2-3 simultaneous streams. Pi4 is better, but still a poor choice. Odds are that you can find a working computer dumped outside someone's home that would work better. Or pay a few bucks for a college surplus pc, or hit up Craigslist.
